instructions: Go to Settings > Apps & Notifications > See all X apps . In the list, find and tap on Google Play Store . Open the Storage & cache section, then tap both Clear storage and Clear cache (older versions of Android use Data instead of Storage ). Restart your phone.

Visit Settings > Apps & notifications and choose See all X apps . At the top of the list, tap the All apps dropdown and change it to Disabled apps . Find Google Play Store and tap on it. Tap on the Enable icon to activate it again.

Launch Settings > Apps & notifications and tap See all X apps . Make sure the top dropdown list says All apps , then find and tap System UI in the list. Select Storage & cache , then Clear cache . Restart your phone.

Open the Google Play Store . Tap on the three horizontal bars in the upper-left corner and select Play Protect . Tap the Settings gear in the top-right corner. Make sure Scan apps with Play Protect is turned on. Tap the Refresh arrow next to the shield icon to run a scan.

Head to Settings > Storage . Under Portable Storage , tap on your microSD card. Tap on the three dots at the upper-right of the screen. Select Storage settings from the context menu. Choose Format , then select Format SD Card.
Go to Settings > System > Advanced > Reset options . Tap Erase all data (factory reset) . Confirm the operation, then enter your passcode to start the process.

My advice is this: try booting up in Safe Mode and see what happens. Reply goku April 2, 2017 at 12:58 am actually I've found the issue is a mix of hardware and software the actual hardware issue is known that is unsteady contact between the tablet and the pins from the case or other wise unsteady connection between the keyboard and tablet ... that's the hardware side the software side is if an app doesn't have a programed response to a change in keyboard state androids default behavior is to kill and restart the app so from the app programmer side the issue would be solved adding one or two lines of code give or take but I don't know if there's an end user solution aside perhaps from buying a new keyboard case Reply Kannon Yamada April 2, 2017 at 1:16 am That's an excellent hardware analysis, thank you for sharing. It sounds then as if the hardware is defective? RCA tablets from Walmart, like the Galileo, IIRC carry a two year warranty. I took a closer look at the pins on the RCA tablets -- they are really flimsy compared to the pogo pins on more expensive devices. It wouldn't surprise me at all if this were the problem. I think there's an option in Android for controlling keyboard behavior. You can configure it to behave differently when a keyboard is connected. You see this option sometimes on devices with physical keyboards. The first time I saw it show up was in Android 5 or 6 IIRC. You might have some luck changing these settings. Shedrack February 24, 2017 at 7:08 pm My phone is TECNO H3 Reply Sheila Strickland February 21, 2017 at 3:22 pm Since the latest (Jan 2017) system update, any app I download that requires internet connection will not work and gives me the following message. "An internal service failure occurred. This can be caused by a lack of network connectivity. Please make sure you have a good network connection." Reply Kannon February 24, 2017 at 3:31 pm Hi Sheila, I have run into this issue and normally it means your internet connection is the culprit. Are you connected to a Wi-Fi network or over a mobile connection? Sometimes your phone may behave differently following a system update. I normally advise attempting a factory reset as it will save you a lot of time troubleshooting all the various causes of this problem. However, there's a good chance that the problem can continue following a factory reset. Try the following before using the nuclear option (factory reset): * Restart your device. * Try disconnecting (forgetting the network) from and reconnecting to your Wi-Fi network -- make sure you have the right network password. * You can also try removing your Google account and then re-adding it. But unless you're familiar with this process, you may want to do a factory reset. * There's also the option of clearing the caches on the Google Play Store, Google Play Services, and Google Framework -- but unless you're familiar with the process, you are better off with a factory reset. Reply Lori February 16, 2017 at 4:37 am For the last month, I've been having a problem with my CM cleaner and other cleaner. I have full Norton coverage, plus the anti-virus software that came with my phone, so I should be covered all around, SAFE PHONE..any way my point is every time I try to clean my phone junk it will remove so much and then the screen goes black, then to my home screen, it does this on all cleaners, sometimes on Google or while playing a game. If you can tell me I would greatly appreciate it. Thank You for your time Reply Kannon February 24, 2017 at 3:25 pm Hi Lori, I wouldn't use any of those anti-virus applications. Google Play Store apps are, overwhelmingly, safer than downloading and installing apps that you find online. In fact, some of those anti-virus programs actually are viruses in disguise. Try uninstalling them. If you continue to experience problems, factory reset your device. That particular code is a data-base entry for a virus. It could be a false positive, a phony anti-virus program, or a real entry. But if you download apps exclusively from the Play Store, then it's probably a phone anti-virus program. Reply Kannon February 15, 2017 at 6:33 pm Hi Patrick, I'm not familiar with that particular device, but I'm assuming it's a white label version of the Android-based set-top-box that's circulating on Amazon. Does it have an Amlogic S905 processor? I ask because many games will not run properly (no matter what you do) on some of the lesser-supported processors. Basically, unless you have a Qualcomm processor, whether or not games run correctly is a game of dice. Much of the reason why is because games are so resource intensive. Many of them are not coded in Java, for this reason. But if they're not written in Java, that means each game's processor much be supported by the app. I suspect that the only way to get the games to run correctly is to request support from the developer. Considering the sheer number of Android boxes based on Amlogic processors out there, the devs might be receptive to any requests. Amlogic processors are, as I understand it, completely open source. In theory, that should make it easier for developers to get their games running on the platform. Reply glenda adams January 21, 2017 at 3:44 am when i am on the phone talking and another call comes in or I get a text message,my phone disconnects.what is causing this and how do I fix it ? My phone is 1 yr old Reply Kannon Y January 21, 2017 at 9:44 am I'm not familiar with this issue. Does your phone disconnect from the cellular tower or the WiFi? What model of phone is it? In general, issues like this can be either hardware, firmware, or software. If it's software, a factory reset SHOULD be able to fix the issue. If the factory reset doesn't work then it's either firmware or hardware. If the hardware is faulty, there's nothing you can do and must return the device under warranty. If the firmware is the cause, the carrier might be able to fix the issue, but your best bet is almost always to RMA (return) the device. Your credit card almost always adds an additional year of warranty to your card: //www.makeuseof.com/tag/get-money-back/ Reply Pravin January 8, 2017 at 3:51 pm I m having a problem on my samsung galaxy note 5 that i cant use any security option of setting nothing works like passcode,pin,fingerprint. But replacing display ic is a risky job sometimes phone may dead perminently. please help me Reply Kannon Y December 14, 2016 at 7:06 pm That's exactly what it sounds like. If there's any damage to the display components on the motherboard, it means no matter what screen you use, the device will remain broken. In theory, you can attempt to troubleshoot this yourself by trying to connect to an external display (unlikely, as you would need to somehow navigate multiple menus in order to switch to an external display). But the most direct solution is to replace the device entirely. Most display components are non-replaceable. That means once they break, there are no DIY means to repair the device. I'm very sorry. Reply bgaskin August 21, 2016 at 3:20 am My phone reboots itself updating or UNinstalling any app. The reboot occurs 0-2s after the app change. Installing an app for the first time is no problem. I have a rooted Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge running Lollipop. I've tried a few cache-clearing / permissions fix ideas. I'm trying to avoid reinstalling the OS if at all possible. My question is what can I do to best identify what's going on, rather than just trying something and seeing? How are the logs on android? Something like Event Viewer for Windows? Or dmesg for linux? What built in logs are there, or what can I install for better logging? I haven't seen anyone post this exact problem anywhere, but if someone's seen it, I'd glad to hear about real-life experience. Reply Kannon Yamada August 22, 2016 at 5:13 pm The problem with root is that it tampers with system files, which can have unpredictable effects on your device. It also dramatically increases the chance that you will at some point in the future need to perform a factory reset. You may, or may not, want to undo root and see if that fixes the problem. However, undoing root oftentimes causes an unbootable device. So you are definitely right that using a log analysis is the correct course of action. For logs, I use CatLog. It's not any different than the other log-catching apps out there. Basically, run the app, cause the crash, and then check the log. It may or may not catch the crash, depending on how sudden it is. Another option is to use the Android Debug Bridge and the development kit. I use this method more often than CatLog (because I've rid myself of root). It's pretty easy to do too, it just requires a fairly large download (Android Studio). Here are the instructions: https://developer.android.com/studio/command-line/logcat.html Reply Vicki August 16, 2016 at 6:19 pm My Android tablet is all of a sudden in a mirror like image and I can't figure out how to reset it Reply Kannon Yamada August 22, 2016 at 5:01 pm I believe that means you've enabled developer options and enabled the RTL (right to left) handling mode. It's designed for single, left-handed operation. You should be able to resolve this by going to Settings --> Developer Options --> and de-checking the RTL mode. If the wallpaper displays, but the apps don't, that could be any number of failures. Have you tried entering the recovery mode or the bootloader? Safe Mode is something I would normally have suggested, since the phone appears to be mostly booting up on its own. Reply simon August 10, 2016 at 3:41 pm everytime I load media on my phone (gallery/whatsapp etc) it grinds to a halt Am using OnePlus 2 Reply Kannon Yamada August 11, 2016 at 7:39 pm That can be almost anything, but a good rule of thumb with smartphones is to never overload the eMMC module. Once you've filled up 75% of the drive's capacity, it will begin slowing down. The best fix is to clear out around a quarter of the capacity and let it sit for 24 hours in airplane mode. Or consider a factory reset. Reply sd May 24, 2015 at 5:49 pm My phone is samsung galaxy A5. Back arrow button on the bottom right corner of the phone gets pressed automatically. The problem doesn't occur always but frequently it happens. Please advise Reply Kannon Y May 24, 2015 at 9:36 pm Sorry for your troubles. When a factory reset doesn't resolve the issue, this is almost always caused by a hardware failure. It can be something as simple as liquid or something conductive inadvertently activating that part of the screen or it can be a failing digitizer. There's a handful of other things that you can try, but none of them will likely work. RMA/return is probably the most time efficient use of your time. Please contact customer service and let them know that you've already tried a factory reset. That should pretty much clear up the options they have available and they'll probably give you an RMA number. Good luck. Reply Kannon Y March 17, 2015 at 7:30 pm The bootloader is a preboot environment where you can factory reset your phone without having to actually load the phone's operating system. From the bootloader you can sometimes access a recovery mode or recovery the operating system. http://www.addictivetips.com/mobile/what-is-bootloader-and-how-to-unlock-bootloader-on-android-phones-complete-guide/ You would need to Google your specific phone and "how to enter bootloader" in order to get details. Most devices include some method of recovering the device from the bootloader (or recovery mode, which is accessible from the bootloader). Reply Kannon Y March 16, 2015 at 8:36 pm Factory resets sometimes fail. Normally, you want your device plugged in while it's resetting. You can also perform a factory reset from the bootloader -- this is more reliable, but might cause you issues. Can you list what service has stopped? There's a lot of causes for these kinds of things -- but oftentimes you can resolve the issue by wiping the cache of the app/service that has failed. It's the same process as the Google Play crashing fix, up at the top. Reply Kannon Y March 16, 2015 at 8:36 pm What I meant by "it's the same process": You would need to wipe the cache/data of the service that is crashing (not Google Play). Even so, I'd much rather have a $350 Nexus 5 over a $640 iPhone 6. The problem with Android phones is that apps can save data to locations with limited space. A lot of music apps cache data in directories with limited space. And then they never run cleanup operations on those locations. I recommend using DiskUsage to locate the places where data is piling up and then uninstalling the app responsible.
